column1: Data Supplied By: National Livestock Reporting Service
Data source: National Livestock Reporting Service
Please see terms of use here: https://www.mla.com.au/general/Terms-and-conditions/data-and-information/

Cattle numbers dropped to 268 penned. The yarding mostly consisted of cows and grown cattle, with a limited offering of young cattle. Not all the usual buying group attended in a generally softer market across the yarding with the exception of bulls which sold dearer.  A limited offering of young cattle made it difficult to quote, in places were to 30c/kg softer. Grown steers slipped 16c and grown heifers sold to 30c/kg softer, numbers and quality a factor.  Heavy cows dropped 17c, and the medium weights sold to 10c/kg softer. Bulls were in demand and gained 20c/kg. 
 
Young cattle sold to the trade from 216c to 344c, while feeders and restockers paid 190c to 320c/kg.  Grown Steers made from 294c to 344c, grown heifers sold to the trade from 210c to 330c, while restockers and feeders paid from 190c to 320c/kg. Manufacturing Beef steers made from 220c to 280c/kg.
 
Heavy cows sold from 254c to 330c/kg. Medium weights cows made from 150c to 250c/kg.  Dairy cows sold from 160c to 182c/kg. Heavy bulls sold from 260c to 330c and the lighter and younger bulls made from 184c to 330c/kg.
 
Market Reporter, Sheona Lamb
